name: chipseq-histone-broad
title: ChIP-seq: Histone Modification Mapping with Broad Peak Calling
description: Map histone modifications (H3K27me3, H3K4me3, H3K9me3, H3K36me3) across the genome using broad peak calling optimized for diffuse chromatin marks. Discover chromatin states, regulatory regions, and epigenetic landscapes.
content:
ğŸ§¬ ChIP-seq: Histone Modification Mapping with Broad Peak Calling

Uncover Chromatin States Through Epigenetic Modifications

Chromatin Immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) for histone modifications reveals the epigenetic landscape of your genome. This specialized pipeline uses broad peak calling optimized for diffuse histone marks like H3K27me3, H3K36me3, and H3K9me3 that spread across chromatin domains.

ğŸ¯ What Are Histone Modifications?

Histones are proteins that package DNA into chromatin. Chemical modifications to histones act as 'epigenetic marks' that control gene expression without changing DNA sequence. These marks can:

  • ğŸ”“ Activate genes: H3K4me3 (promoters), H3K27ac (enhancers), H3K36me3 (gene bodies)

  • ğŸ”’ Silence genes: H3K27me3 (Polycomb repression), H3K9me3 (heterochromatin)

  • ğŸ“Š Mark chromatin states: Combinatorial patterns define regulatory elements

  • ğŸ§¬ Regulate development: Control cell differentiation and tissue specification

ğŸ¨ Common Histone Marks and Their Biological Roles

ğŸ”“ Active Chromatin Marks

  • H3K4me3: Active promoters, transcription start sites (TSS)

  • H3K27ac: Active enhancers, super-enhancers, regulatory elements

  • H3K4me1: Enhancers, primed/poised regulatory regions

  • H3K36me3: Active gene bodies, transcription elongation

ğŸ”’ Repressive Chromatin Marks

  • H3K27me3: Polycomb-mediated repression, developmentally silenced genes

  • H3K9me3: Constitutive heterochromatin, repetitive elements

  • H3K9me2: Facultative heterochromatin, tissue-specific silencing

âš™ï¸ Broad vs Narrow Peak Calling

This pipeline uses BROAD peak calling - essential for histone modifications:

  • ğŸŒŠ Broad peaks: Detect diffuse signals across large chromatin domains (10-100kb)

    • Perfect for: H3K27me3, H3K36me3, H3K9me3, H3K79me2

    • Algorithm: MACS2/MACS3 with --broad flag (broad_cutoff = 0.1)

    • Captures: Extended enrichment regions, chromatin domains

  • ğŸ“ Narrow peaks (not this pipeline): Sharp, focused signals (100-1000bp)

    • Better for: Transcription factors, H3K4me3, H3K27ac

    • Use: Separate narrow peak pipeline for TF ChIP-seq

ğŸ§ª Experimental Design Requirements

Essential Components

  • ğŸ§« ChIP samples: Immunoprecipitated DNA with histone-specific antibody

  • ğŸ¯ Input controls: Total chromatin without IP (critical for normalization)

  • ğŸ”¬ Biological replicates: Minimum 2 replicates per condition (3+ recommended)

  • ğŸ“Š Sequencing depth: 20-40 million reads per sample for mammalian genomes

Data Quality Metrics

  • âœ… FRiP score: Fraction of Reads in Peaks > 1-5% for histone marks

  • âœ… Cross-correlation: NSC > 1.05, RSC > 0.8

  • âœ… Library complexity: > 80% non-duplicate reads

ğŸ“‹ Sample Sheet Format

Your CSV samplesheet defines experimental structure:

Column Descriptions:

  • sample: Unique sample name

  • fastq_1: Read 1 file (or single-end reads)

  • fastq_2: Read 2 file (leave empty for single-end)

  • replicate: Biological replicate number (1, 2, 3...)

  • antibody: Histone mark name (H3K27me3, H3K36me3, etc.)

  • control: Name of matching input control sample

  • control_replicate: Replicate number of control sample

ğŸ§¬ Reference Genome Selection

Choose appropriate genome for your organism:

  • ğŸ§‘ Human: GRCh38/hg38 (latest) or GRCh37/hg19 (legacy studies)

  • ğŸ­ Mouse: GRCm39/mm39 (latest) or GRCm38/mm10 (legacy)

  • ğŸ”¬ Model organisms: Zebrafish, fly, C. elegans, yeast

  • ğŸŒ± Plants: Arabidopsis TAIR10, rice, maize

ğŸ“Š Comprehensive Results

Peak Files

  • ğŸ“ BroadPeak files: Genomic coordinates of enriched regions (BED format)

  • ğŸ¯ Consensus peaks: Reproducible peaks across biological replicates

  • ğŸ“Š Peak annotations: Gene assignments, genomic features, distances to TSS

  • ğŸ§® Peak statistics: Signal enrichment, fold-change, FDR values

Visualization Tracks

  • ğŸ¨ BigWig files: Normalized signal tracks for genome browsers (IGV, UCSC)

  • ğŸ“ˆ Coverage plots: Signal distribution around genes and features

  • ğŸ”¥ Heatmaps: Signal intensity across regions of interest

Quality Control

  • ğŸ“ˆ MultiQC Report: Comprehensive QC with interactive plots

  • ğŸ” Fragment analysis: Insert size distributions, read quality metrics

  • ğŸ“Š Cross-correlation: Library quality scores (NSC, RSC)

  • âœ… FRiP scores: Fraction of reads in peaks per sample

  • ğŸ¯ Replicate concordance: IDR analysis for reproducibility

Differential Analysis (Optional)

  • ğŸ”„ Differential binding: Changes between conditions (e.g., WT vs KO)

  • ğŸ“Š Statistical testing: DESeq2 analysis for significant changes

  • ğŸ¨ Volcano plots: Visualization of differential peaks

ğŸ”¬ Biological Applications

  • ğŸ§¬ Chromatin states: Map active/repressive domains across genome

  • ğŸ”¬ Development: Track epigenetic changes during differentiation

  • ğŸ©º Cancer research: Identify aberrant silencing in tumors

  • ğŸ’Š Drug discovery: Assess epigenetic drug effects

  • ğŸ§« Stem cells: Characterize pluripotency and lineage commitment

  • ğŸŒ¿ Plant biology: Study vernalization and stress responses

âš™ï¸ Pipeline Specifications

  • ğŸ”§ Aligner: BWA-MEM (default, robust and accurate)

  • ğŸ“ Peak caller: MACS2 with --broad flag (broad_cutoff = 0.1)

  • ğŸ¯ Duplicate handling: Marked and filtered (prevents PCR bias)

  • ğŸ“Š Normalization: CPM (counts per million) for BigWig tracks

  • âœ… Quality filters: MAPQ â‰¥ 20, properly paired reads
